overview_of_class: Interdisciplinary analysis of the political, economic and ethical questions underlying the modern climate crisis, including discussion of sustainability concepts, a review of the evidence for human-induced climate change, political and economic analysis of mitigation scenarios, and an exploration of the ethics of resource use, conservation practices, and environmentalism.
name: Climate Change and Sustainability: Economic and Ethical Dimensions
title: WCAS PHIL 270-0-20 Climate Change and Sustainability: Economic and Ethical Dimensions

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Interdisciplinary analysis of the political, economic and ethical questions underlying the modern climate crisis, including discussion of sustainability concepts, a review of the evidence for human-induced climate change, political and economic analysis of mitigation scenarios, and an exploration of the ethics of resource use, conservation practices, and environmentalism.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
-Students will understand the principles of sustainability and their historical development.
-Students will understand the basic components and main processes of the Earth's climate system.
-Students will understand the main lines of scientific evidence pertaining to the global warming hypothesis.
-Students will develop an understanding of basic economic analysis and its application to environmental issues
-Students will understand empirical evidence regarding the forecast economic effects of global warming
-Students will understand analyses of the use and anticipated consequences of political and regulatory mechanisms
-Students will develop an understanding of some of the core normative principles of ethical theory and environmental ethics.
-Students will learn to utilize normative principles in the analysis of complex empirical phenomena related to climate change.
